supporting_spans: M. de Villefort received the following note: “The person called the Count of Monte Cristo is an intimate acquaintance of Lord Wilmore, a rich foreigner, who is sometimes seen in Paris and who is there at this moment; he is also known to the Abbé Busoni, a Sicilian priest, of high repute in the Eas

He was no longer astonished when he searched on to find in the register this note, placed in 1815, which read: “The person called the Count of Monte Cristo is an intimate acquaintance of Lord Wilmore, a rich foreigner, who is sometimes seen in Paris and who is there at this moment; he is also known to the Abbé Busoni, a Sicilian priest, of high repute in the East”
reasoning: Evidence supports: The evidence from the novel directly states that Noirtier handed the conspiracy dossier to a British spy and that Monte Cristo later acquired it. This supports the claim that Noirtier pre-emptively handed the conspiracy dossier to a British spy—the very file the Count of Monte Cri

analysis.claim_text: Learning that Villefort meant to denounce him to Louis XVIII, Noirtier pre-emptively handed the conspiracy dossier to a British spy—the very file the Count of Monte Cristo later acquired—thereby engineering his son’s “lawful” murder.

sub_claims.text: Noirtier learned that Villefort meant to denounce him to Louis XVIII.
Noirtier handed the conspiracy dossier to a British spy.
The Count of Monte Cristo acquired the conspiracy dossier.

analysis.reasoning: Evidence supports: The evidence from the novel directly states that Noirtier handed the conspiracy dossier to a British spy and that Monte Cristo later acquired it. This supports the claim that Noirtier pre-emptively handed the conspiracy dossier to a British spy—the very file the Count of Monte Cristo later acquired—thereby engineering his son’s ‘lawful’ murder.
